meanings.def: the air that you take into your lungs and send out again
examples: His breath smelt of garlic.
bad breath (= that smells bad)
She was very short of breath (= had difficulty breathing).
Patients develop a cough and shortness of breath.
There was a sharp intake of breath in the courtroom.
We had to stop for breath before we got to the top.
While there is breath left in my body, I will refuse.
He came up out of the water gasping for breath.
His breath came in short gasps.
I could smell gin on her breath.
I felt a bit short of breath and had to sit down.
She could feel his warm breath against her cheek.
She poured out her story, hardly pausing for breath.
Smoking gives you bad breath.

meanings.def: an amount of air that enters the lungs at one time
examples: Take a deep breath and try to relax.
He recited the whole poem in one breath.
He sucked in a deep breath.
He let out a long breath.
How can we trust a government that mentions community care and cutbacks in the same breath?
I opened the window and took a deep breath.
Take slow, calm breaths until you feel your heartbeat slowing down.

meanings.def: a small amount of something; slight evidence of something
examples: a breath of suspicion/scandal

meanings.def: a slight movement of air
examples: It was a still day, without a breath of wind.

meanings.def: clean air breathed in after being indoors or in a dirty atmosphere
examples: We'll get a breath of fresh air at lunchtime.
I'm going outside for a breath of fresh air.

meanings.def: a person, thing or place that is new and different and therefore interesting and exciting
examples: The new secretary is a breath of fresh air.

meanings.def: an essential part of a person’s existence
examples: Playing the violin has been the breath of life to her for over 20 years.

meanings.def: to stop breathing for a moment because of fear, shock, etc.
examples: When he said he had resigned, I caught my breath in surprise.

meanings.def: to start to be able to breathe normally again after running or doing exercise that makes you tired
to stop doing something and rest
examples: She talks all the time and hardly stops to draw breath.
He spoke solidly for twenty minutes, barely pausing to draw breath.

meanings.def: to live; to be alive
examples: He was as kind a man as ever drew breath.

meanings.def: to breathe normally again after running or doing exercise that makes you tired
examples: I needed a few minutes to get my breath back after the run.
She paused to catch her breath.

meanings.def: to stop breathing for a short time
examples: Hold your breath and count to ten.
How long can you hold your breath for?

meanings.def: to be nervous while you are waiting for something that you are anxious about
examples: He held his breath while the results were read out.

meanings.def: people say don’t hold your breath! to emphasize that something will take a long time or may not happen
examples: She said she'd do it this week, but don't hold your breath!

meanings.def: immediately after saying something that suggests the opposite intention or meaning
examples: He praised my work and in the same breath told me I would have to leave.

meanings.def: the last moment of a person’s life
having difficulty breathing after exercise
examples: We were out of breath after only five minutes.
I'm a bit out of breath after my run.

meanings.def: used to tell somebody that it is not worth wasting time and effort saying something because it will not change anything
examples: Save your breath—you'll never persuade her.
It's useless talking to him—you may as well save your breath.

meanings.def: to say something quietly so that people cannot hear
examples: ‘Rubbish!’ she muttered under her breath.
He was whispering rude remarks about her under his breath.

meanings.def: to be very surprising or beautiful
examples: My first view of the island from the air took my breath away.
The sheer audacity of the man took my breath away.

meanings.def: to say something that nobody takes any notice of
examples: You're just wasting your breath. She never listens.

meanings.def: feeling very anxious or excited
examples: We waited with bated breath for the winner to be announced.
We waited for the decision with bated breath.
